comments.text:
Refreshes the Auth Token for the Logged-in User.

Not required in general practice, as the Token Refresh process is taken care of, automatically by the Directus SDK Client.

parameters.functionScript: Outputs.accountData = { "name":"Default account" }

comments.text:
1. Before using this component, do make sure that you have imported the Directus SDK. To do so, you could add the following code in the 'Head Code' setting:
--------------------------------
<script type="module">
  import * as Directus from "https://esm.sh/@directus/sdk";
  window.Directus = Directus;
</script>
--------------------------------

2. This component creates a separate Directus SDK Client, dedicated for use by the App (without any user login). It will operate parallely with the Directus SDK Client that is linked to the 'logged-in user'.

You have the option to initialize this (Site Client) with either a Static Token (https://docs.directus.io/guides/sdk/authentication.html#create-a-directus-client-with-a-token) or the default 'Public' Access Role, by keeping the static_token property empty.

parameters.functionScript:
const url = Noodl.Objects.DirectusSDK?.Client?.url?.origin || null;

if(!url) Outputs.Do()

comments.text:
❗ ⚠️ Warning ⚠️ ❗

The usage of Flows, especially as Cloud Functions, has to be properly secured.

Do check out the Docs to ensure that the Security of your Directus backend has been ensured before you execute Flows using this component!

1. It is recommended to use POST based Flows, whenever possible
2. In the case of GET based Flows, make sure to provide valid 'query parameters' only

comments.text:
This Utility component tries to first retrieve the Site SDK Client, if installed, and if not, the User SDK Client then.
Outputs the retrieved Client.

If none is available, throws an error.
This component is used to make sure that the SDK Client is properly available.

components.name: /#Directus/Directus Prefab/Initial Set Up/Set up Directus - Option 1 (env)

comments.text: Make sure to have "env.json" set up properly

There are 2 options to include the URL of your Directus project's URL (and optionally, Static Token):

1. Using an environment file (env.json) [For ease of management, and not security]
2. Directly setting the URL

PS: Choose only 1 and remove the other!
Is the SDK installed and ready to use?

components.name: /#Directus/Directus Prefab/Initial Set Up/Set up Directus - Option 2 (manual)

comments.text:
There are 2 options to include the URL of your Directus project's URL (and optionally, Static Token):

1. Using an environment file (env.json) [For ease of management, and not security]
2. Directly setting the URL

PS: Choose only 1 and remove the other!

This is Option 2 :

- Provide env values directly in Noodl

dynamicports.name: inputMappingScript
inputMappingScript
inputMappingScript
inputMappingScript

history.content: Take an input array of objects, output an array of only the 'Video_id' field of each object

This function takes an array of objects from the Inputs.InputArray and creates a new array containing only the 'Video_id' field from each object. If the operation is successful, it sends the new array to the Outputs.VideoIds output and triggers the Outputs.Success signal. If an error occurs during the process, it sends the error message to the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure signal.
Format an input number of seconds as HH:MM:SS so 130 seconds would be 00:02:10

This function takes an input number of seconds and formats it into a time string in the format of HH:MM:SS. The Inputs.Seconds input is the number of seconds to be formatted. The function first checks if the input is a number. If not, it throws an error. Then, it calculates the hours, minutes, and remaining seconds from the input number. Each unit of time is padded with leading zeros to ensure a two-digit format. The units are then joined with a colon (:) to form the time string. The formatted time string is set as the Outputs.FormattedTime output. Finally, the function triggers the Outputs.Success output signal to indicate that the operation was successful.
Round the seconds value to an integer

This function takes an input of seconds and converts it into a time format (HH:MM:SS). The function first rounds the Inputs.Seconds to the nearest integer using the Math.round() function. It then checks if the input is a number, throwing an error if it is not. The function calculates the hours, minutes, and remaining seconds from the input seconds. It then formats these values into a time string, padding each unit with leading zeros if necessary. The formatted time is then set as the Outputs.FormattedTime and the function signals a successful operation with the Outputs.Success output.

dynamicports.name: inputMappingScript

history.content: filter out items from an input array that have a 'start' field greater than or equal to an input start integer, and also the same 'start' field is less than the 'end' integer input

This function filters an array based on a specified range. It takes an Inputs.Array, Inputs.Start, and Inputs.End as inputs. The function goes through each item in the array and checks if the 'start' field of the item is greater than or equal to the 'Start' input and less than the 'End' input. The filtered array is then sent to the Outputs.FilteredArray output. If the operation is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the operation, it sets the Outputs.error output with the error message and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

dynamicports.name: inputMappingScript

parameters.text: Upload your intros and outros here:

history.content: Take in 3 input ids and combine them into an array of ids of form { "id": intValue }

This function takes three inputs: Inputs.Id1, Inputs.Id2, and Inputs.Id3. It checks if these inputs are valid and if they are, it combines them into an array of objects. Each object in the array has a single property, "id", which is set to the value of the corresponding input. The resulting array is then sent to the Outputs.IdArray output. If the function executes successfully, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there is an error during the process, for example, if the inputs are not valid, the function outputs the error message to the Outputs.error output and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
There may only be one id. Can the script generate the array dynamically depending on which ids inputs are non null

This function generates an array of IDs based on the non-null inputs. It takes three inputs: Inputs.Id1, Inputs.Id2, and Inputs.Id3. It checks each input and if it is not null, it adds it to the array. If no valid ID is found (all inputs are null), it sets the Outputs.error output to 'No valid id found' and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal. If at least one valid ID is found, it sets the Outputs.IdArray output to the array of IDs and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal.

roots.type: /#Directus/Directus Prefab/Initial Set Up/Set up Directus - Option 1 (env)

history.content: Take an input object and append a string field 'type' to it, then output the new object

This function takes an input object and a type string, appends the type string as a 'type' field to the input object, and outputs the new object. It takes Inputs.InputObject and Inputs.Type as inputs. It then appends the 'type' field to the input object with the value of the Type input. If no Type input is provided, it defaults to 'default'. The function then sets the Outputs.OutputObject to the new object with the appended 'type' field and triggers the Outputs.Success output signal.
Upload a video blob from a file picker node to an Azure storage account

This function uploads a video file to an Azure storage account. It takes four inputs: Inputs.File, which is the file from a file picker node; Inputs.SasToken, which is the Shared Access Signature (SAS) token; Inputs.StorageAccountName, which is the name of the Azure storage account; and Inputs.ContainerName, which is the name of the Azure storage container. The function constructs the URL for the Azure Blob Storage service and sends a PUT request to upload the file. If the upload is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the upload, it sets the Outputs.error output with the error message and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.
Upload a video blob from a file picker node to an Azure storage account

This function uploads a video file to an Azure storage account. It takes four inputs: Inputs.File, which is the file from a file picker node; Inputs.SasToken, which is the Shared Access Signature (SAS) token; Inputs.StorageAccountName, which is the name of the Azure storage account; and Inputs.ContainerName, which is the name of the Azure storage container. The function constructs the URL for the Azure Blob Storage service and sends a PUT request to upload the file. If the upload is successful, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal. If there's an error during the upload, it sets the Outputs.error output with the error message and triggers the Outputs.Failure output signal.

parameters.functionScript:
const bytes = Inputs.Bytes || 0; // Get the input bytes, default to 0 if not provided

if (bytes < 0) throw new Error('Invalid number of bytes'); // Throw an error if the number of bytes is negative

const megabytes = bytes / (1024 * 1024); // Convert bytes to megabytes

const roundedMegabytes = Math.round(megabytes * 100) / 100; // Round the result to 2 decimal places

Outputs.Megabytes = roundedMegabytes; // Output the result
Outputs.Success(); // Signal success

history.content: convert input number of bytes into MB

metadata.code:
const bytes = Inputs.Bytes || 0; // Get the input bytes, default to 0 if not provided

if (bytes < 0) throw new Error('Invalid number of bytes'); // Throw an error if the number of bytes is negative

const megabytes = bytes / (1024 * 1024); // Convert bytes to megabytes

Outputs.Megabytes = megabytes; // Output the result
Outputs.Success(); // Signal success

history.content: This function converts a number of bytes into megabytes. It takes Inputs.Bytes as an input, checks if the number of bytes is negative and throws an error if it is. Then, it converts the bytes into megabytes by dividing the number of bytes by 1024 twice (since 1 megabyte is 1024 kilobytes and 1 kilobyte is 1024 bytes). The result is then set as the Outputs.Megabytes output. Finally, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal to indicate that the conversion was successful.
Round the result to 2 decimal places

metadata.code:
const bytes = Inputs.Bytes || 0; // Get the input bytes, default to 0 if not provided

if (bytes < 0) throw new Error('Invalid number of bytes'); // Throw an error if the number of bytes is negative

const megabytes = bytes / (1024 * 1024); // Convert bytes to megabytes

const roundedMegabytes = Math.round(megabytes * 100) / 100; // Round the result to 2 decimal places

Outputs.Megabytes = roundedMegabytes; // Output the result
Outputs.Success(); // Signal success

history.content: This function converts a given number of bytes into megabytes and rounds the result to two decimal places. It takes Inputs.Bytes as an input, checks if the number of bytes is not negative, and then converts the bytes to megabytes. The result is then rounded to two decimal places. The rounded result is then set as the Outputs.Megabytes output. After the conversion and rounding process is completed successfully, it triggers the Outputs.Success output signal.

parameters.functionScript:
// Refresh the current window
window.location.reload();

history.content: Refresh the current window

This function refreshes the current window in the web browser. It uses the built-in JavaScript function `window.location.reload()` to refresh or reload the current document. This function does not have any inputs or outputs.
